Atlas Iron (AGO AT)

ASIA

US Commerce Secretary Ross said US President Trump is interested to see how new duties impact China talks and noted there was no breakthrough in US-China talks last week. (Newswires)


UK/EU

UK PM May and Chancellor Hammond are reported to clash regarding the budget. (The Sun)

UK PM May refused to say whether she thinks the UK will be better or worse off in the event of a 'no-deal' Brexit and stated the government is working to make a success of leaving the EU "whatever the outcome of the negotiations". (Sky)

Ireland’s Foreign Minister Coveney said chances of a no deal Brexit are very slim as no one would benefit and that it is possible to get a deal on Brexit well before the year-end, while Coveney added that talks of surviving a no deal Brexit is more of a negotiation tactic than a reality. (Newswires)


FX

South Africa's ANC stated that the expropriation bill has been withdrawn. (Newswires)
 

COMMODITIES

US API Weekly Crude Stocks +38k vs. Exp. -700k (Prev. -5.170mln). (Newswires)

CME cut initial margin requirement for front-month WTI contract by 10% to USD 3,100 from USD 3,450 previously. (Newswires)

Iran oil shipments are reportedly declining at a faster-than-expected pace ahead of US sanctions which begin in November, while Iran reportedly expects crude exports to fall by a third in September. (WSJ)

Mexico's incoming government is mulling an 'indefinite' suspension of competitive auctions for oil and gas producers and Pemex venture partners and is to consider withdrawing IEA and forge closer ties with OPEC, according to a document. (Newswires)


GEOPOLITICAL

US Secretary of Defense Mattis suggested the US could resume military drills in the Korean peninsula which were suspended after the Trump-Kim summit, in which he stated that the US had no plans at this time to suspend any more exercises. (Axios)
 

US

US Senate confirmed Richard Clarida for Fed vice-chair. (Newswires)

Fed Discount Rate Minutes stated 2 Regional banks supported a hike at the July meeting and 10 backed no changes to the discount rate. Furthermore, the minutes noted that Kansas City (George) and Cleveland (Mester) urged raising discount rate by 0.25% due to the continued solid economic growth outlook, tight labour markets and inflation remaining near 2%, but the remaining 10 wanted to maintain as they felt it was appropriate during the current economic conditions. (Newswires)

US Treasury Secretary Mnuchin said he expects a trade agreement with Canada can conclude this week and does not expect a lot of sticking points on the trade talks with Canada, while he repeated that US will focus on Mexico if talks with Canada fall through. (Newswires)

US Commerce Secretary Ross said the US is asking Canada to consider joining the US-Mexico trade deal but also noted that Canada has made troubles in drugs and biologics for US firms, while he also stated that the US is not accusing Mexico of currency manipulation as the MXN has been falling which impacts US trade deficit. (Newswires)

White House Economist Hasset said the clock is ticking for Canada and that if Canada doesn’t sign on by Friday, “the train might start to leave the station”. (Newswires)

US Senate Majority Leader McConnell said the trade deal between US & Mexico is not a bad agreement and added the senate has to wait until interactions with Canada are complete before making forward judgement. Elsewhere, US Senate Majority Leader McConnell is also said to hope to get the spending bill to President Trump by September. (Newswires)

Canadian PM Trudeau said his position on supply hasn't changed but looks forward to a NAFTA deal if it is good for Canada, while he added there has been progress on autos and Canada is studying the US-Mexico terms of the deal. Elsewhere, Canadian Foreign Minister Freeland said we are encouraged by progress between US and Mexico in which progress on autos and labor were particularly helpful. (Newswires)

US Wholesale Inventories Adv Jun 0.7% (Prev. 0.1%). (Newswires)
US Retail Inventories Ex-Auto Adv Jun 0.1% (Prev. 0.2%, Rev. 0.0%)
US Adv Goods Trade Balance Jun -72.20B (Prev. -67.92B)
US Consumer Confidence Jul 133.4 vs. Exp. 126.5 (Prev. 127.4, Rev. 127.9)

MARKET RECAP

Best Buy (BBY) was lower after its earnings report, which saw beats on the top and bottom lines, and raised its FY19 guidance. However, it forecast Q3 EPS lower than consensus and beneath the previous year’s figures. Tiffany’s (TIF) was slightly higher after earnings and revenue beats, as well firmer outlook for FY18. AMD (AMD) promoted Saeid Moshkelani to senior vice president and general manager, as Jim Anderson left to become CEO of Lattice Semiconductor (LSCC). Coty (COTY) soared after an upgrade to overweight from equal weight at Morgan Stanley. Qualcomm (QCOM) announced the preliminary results of its tender offer which said it sold 76mln shares at or below USD 67.50 in cash. US President Trump says Facebook (FB), Twitter (TWTR) & Alphabet (GOOGL) had better be careful, and US tech giants are treading on troubled territory. This follows from pre-market tweeting from Trump stating Google’s (GOOGL) search engine is “rigged” and that it will be “addressed”. Starbucks (SBUX) and Nestle (NESN SW) announced they have now closed the $7.15bln licensing deal which gives permission to Nestle to sell products from SBUX outside of their coffee shops, which will result in 500 employees from Starbucks moving to Nestle. SPX +0.03% at 2897, NDX +0.15% at 7570, DJI +0.60% at 26065.

The treasury complex drifted lower on Tuesday, after trading within a tight range overnight, as US and Mexico were optimistic about a trade agreement coming soon with Canada. A strong Consumer Confidence reading also contributed to some weakness across the complex, pushing equities to a new record high. Amid decent volume, the yield curve steepened with most of the action concentrated in the belly and long end of the curve where yields were higher by c.3bps. US 10-year T-notes settled 8 ticks lower at 120-30.

RANsquawk US Market Wrap - 28th August 2018: Canada re-joins negotiating table; deal expected to come this week
content:
To download the report, please click here
If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal.
To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category.

  • SNAP-SHOT: Equities up, Treasuries down, crude down, dollar flat.
  • REAR-VIEW: US-Mexico to focus on relationship with Canada; ECB's Praet (Dovish) reiterated ECB guidance; $37bln 5yr Note Auction stops-through by 0.1bps; South Africa's ANC withdraws expropriation bill
  • AHEAD: BoJ's Suzuki to speak; US GDP 2nd Estimate & Pending Home Sales; German GfK Consumer Sentiment; US to sell $31bln in 7yr notes.

* US-MEXICO TRADE: Following yesterday’s announcement of a new US -Mexico bilateral trade deal, focus on Tuesday fell on the trade relationship with Canada. US Commerce Secretary Ross stressed Canada’s necessity for a trade deal with the US, asking Canada to consider joining the US-Mexico trade deal. He also claimed the US is not accusing Mexico of currency manipulation as the MXN has been falling and is impacting the US trade deficit. Also, US Treasury Secretary Mnuchin reiterated he sees a trade agreement with Canada coming this week, as he does not expect a lot of sticking points in the trade talks. He restated that if talks with Canada fall through, the US will focus on Mexico, mentioning this deal with Mexico has strong currency chapter. He also noted he does not expect auto prices to rise following the new agreement. On the Mexican front, Economy Minister Guajardo said there will be free trade on North American auto market and indicated the outstanding issues with Canada include dairy and government procurement. Elsewhere, Canada's PM Trudeau said his position on supply hasn't changed, but he looks forward to a NAFTA deal if it is good for Canada, adds there has been progress on auto's and Canada is studying the US-Mexico terms of the deal.

* CHINA TRADE TALKS: On China, US Treasury Secretary Mnuchin claimed tariffs are about US workers and US economy and clarified they are not trying to hurt China whilst he urged for better US access in Chinese markets. NEC director Kudlow said he believes China is on the defensive as the US is showing momentum in trade talks and finally Commerce Secretary Ross said Trump is interested to see how new duties impact China talks but reiterated there has been no breakthrough in the talks last week.

* GEOPOLITICS: An internal memo reported France has told diplomats to delay any non-essential trips to Iran due to a foiled bomb plot as well as a tougher attitude towards France from Tehran. Separately, Germany said to be looking at other options to aid Turkey, as opposed to financial help, in response to WSJ article stating they were to offer financial aid. This came amid suggestions from a German official that they could consider bilateral aid in the form of untied financial credits, adding “[they] would do a lot to try to stabilize Turkey [they] don’t have much choice." Saudi Energy Adviser says Iran is unable to completely, or partially, close the Straits of Hormuz or Bab Al-Mandab, following from US Secretary of State Pompeo’s comments who noted Iran does not control the Stait of Hormuz. Defence Secretary Mattis also on the matter said Iran has been put on notice and they will be held accountable for mischief throughout the region. The Saudi Energy Minister also does not see current US sanctions stopping Iranian exports completely; as a reminder the energy related sanctions against Iran are to come into effect in November.

* FED: Fed’s Kashkari (Dove, Non-Voter) said expansions do not last forever and the Fed is aiming at extending one; he added the effects of monetary policy operate with a lag.

* DISCOUNT RATE MINUTES: 2 Regional banks supported a hike at the July meeting and the remaining 10 decided to leave rates unchanged. Kansas City (George) and Cleveland (Mester)  urged raising the discount rate by 0.25% due to the continued solid economic growth outlook, tight labour markets, and with inflation remaining near 2%. However, the remaining 10 wanted to maintain the rate as they felt it was appropriate during the current economic conditions.  

* BREXIT:  An article published in PoliticsHome reported the UK Government might not spell out risks of no-deal Brexit before crunch Commons vote, Downing Street has refused to confirm whether MPs will be told the full consequences of a no-deal Brexit before they get the chance to vote for one in Parliament. In later trade, it was reported UK PM May refused to say whether she thinks the UK will be better or worse off in the event of a 'no-deal' Brexit telling Sky News the government is working to make a success of leaving the EU "whatever the outcome of the negotiations”. Ireland’s Foreign Minister Coveney said the chances of a no deal Brexit are very slim as no one would benefit and it is possible to get a deal on Brexit well before the year end. He then went on to note talks of surviving a no deal Brexit is more of a negotiation tactic than a reality. US Treasury Sec. Mnuchin said the US is very much ready to do a trade deal with the UK and French President Macron said the EU is working to avoid a domino effect following Brexit.

* ECB: ECB's Praet (Dovish) reiterated patient, prudent and persistent monetary policy is still needed, and the risk channel of policy has to be closely monitored.

* SPX +0.03% at 2897, NDX +0.15% at 7570, DJI +0.60% at 26065. SECTORS: Energy -0.45%, Materials -0.34%, Industrials -0.12%, Cons Discretionary +0.18%, Cons Staples -0.32%, Healthcare +0.1%, Financials -0.1%, Tech +0.2%, Telecoms -0.47%, Utilities -0.21%.

* EARNINGS: Best Buy (BBY) was lower after its earnings report, which saw beats on the top and bottom lines, and raised its FY19 guidance. However, it forecast Q3 EPS lower than consensus and beneath the previous year’s figures. Tiffany’s (TIF) was slightly higher after earnings and revenue beats, as well firmer outlook for FY18.

* STOCK SPECIFICS: AMD (AMD) promoted Saeid Moshkelani to senior vice president and general manager, as Jim Anderson left to become CEO of Lattice Semiconductor (LSCC). Coty (COTY) soared after an upgrade to overweight from equal weight at Morgan Stanley. Qualcomm (QCOM) announced the preliminary results of its tender offer which said it sold 76mln shares at or below USD 67.50 in cash. US President Trump says Facebook (FB), Twitter (TWTR) & Alphabet (GOOGL) had better be careful, and US tech giants are treading on troubled territory. This follows from pre-market tweeting from Trump stating Google’s (GOOGL) search engine is “rigged” and that it will be “addressed”.

* M&A: Starbucks (SBUX) and Nestle (NESN SW) announced they have now closed the $7.15bln licensing deal which gives permission to Nestle to sell products from SBUX outside of their coffee shops, which will result in 500 employees from Starbucks moving to Nestle

* WTI (V8) SETTLES 34 CENTS LOWER AT $68.53/BBL; BRENT (V8) SETTLES  26 CENTS LOWER AT $75.95/BBL.

Oil futures held in positive territory for most of the morning session supported by positive risk sentiment which attracted investors into the energy complex and kept equities higher in early trade. However, WTI gave up its gains heading into negative territory following  strong US Consumer Confidence data which contributed to a USD rebound. Further, looming Iranian supply shortages continue to upward pressures even after reassuring comments from Saudi Arabia’s energy minister who downplayed the impact of US sanctions stating they are unlikely to stop Iranian exports completely. Citi also sees ‘the apparent drop in Iranian export shipments for August as supportive’ though they note seasonal variability may be exaggerating the effect of looming US sanctions. Iraq Prime Minister also said to be optimistic of continued rise in oil prices. In later trade, it was reported the Mexico's incoming government is mulling an 'indefinite' suspension of competitive auctions for oil and gas producers and pemex venture partners and is to consider withdrawing IEA and forge closer ties with OPEC.

Tonight’s API data Crude is expected to show a drawdown of 700k barrels, Cushing expecting a draw of 42k barrels (according to Genscape), distillates expecting a build of 1.6mln barrels and gasoline expected to report a build of 400k barrels.

* US 10-YEAR T-NOTES SETTLED 8 TICKS LOWER AT 120-30: The treasury complex drifted lower on Tuesday, after trading within a tight range overnight, as US and Mexico were optimistic about a trade agreement coming soon with Canada. A strong Consumer Confidence reading also contributed to some weakness across the complex, pushing equities to a new record high. Amid decent volume, the yield curve steepened with most of the action  concentrated in the belly and long end of the curve where yields were higher by c.3bps.

The US sold $37bln in 5yr notes today with not much fireworks, the auction stopped through by 0.1bps at 2.745%. The bid to cover came in at 2.39x beneath the average of 2.52 where it showed the lowest BC since April. Dealers took just shy of 25%, better than the average of 28%,  Directs took 9% and Indirects took 66%, higher than the average of 61.2%.

* DXY: Lost grip of previous August lows amidst widespread Greenback weakness and retreats vs EMs, with the index through 94.500 and down near 94.425 before regaining some composure after a jump in US consumer confidence.

* CAD, CHF: A real tussle to end Tuesday’s EU session ahead of the G10 pack, with the Loonie making a late charge on the back of latest US-Canada trade comments via Mnuchin who claims that a deal, aka Mexico, may be struck this week and he does not foresee many contentious issues to be resolved. USDCAD moved down through 1.2900, though reclaimed that level on more trade-related comments  from Ross and Guajardo.  The Franc that continues to test the same key tech support circa 0.9750 on more short covering and positional adjustment.

 * EUR, NZD: The next best majors and grinding out gains vs the USD for much of the day, with the single currency up through 1.1700 for the majority of the session before it fell back beneath the level amid the USD rebound. Kiwi extended its rebound from recent lows a bit further above 0.6700 on a broad improvement in risk sentiment.

* GBP, AUD, JPY: A bit more reluctant to join the overall trend with Cable unable to really build on 1.2900+ levels and the Pound slipping to fresh multi-month lows vs the Eur (around 0.9080) on heightened risk of a hard or no deal Brexit. Meanwhile, political instability and the US-China trade impasse continue to hamper the AUD around 0.7350, while USDJPY  remained anchored to 111.00.

* EM: TRY and ZAR among the big movers yet again, and both very volatile, with the Lira retesting lows vs the USD in the 6.2000+ area, then paring declines briefly on reports that Germany may be mulling financial assistance for Turkey, before re-weakening on later headlines suggesting that the aid being considered is not in cash form. Similarly, the Rand got a boost on the news that SA’s expropriation bill proposed by the ANC has been withdrawn, but fell back when details revealed that the constitutional change is still on the agenda for review. USDZAR down through 14.0000 at one stage vs 14.2425 at the high, and now circa 14.2000.

AUCTION PREVIEW: US to auction USD 37bln of 5-year notes on 28 August 2018 at 1300 EST/1800 BST
content: US to sell USD 104bln in 2-year (USD 36bln, Monday) 5-year (USD 37bln, Tuesday) and 7-year (USD 31bln, Thursday) paper this week, with all settling on 31 August. The Fed will add on USD 2.5bln of 2s to its SOMA portfolio, USD 2.6bln of 5s, and USD 2.2bln of 7s. “Similar to the 2y auctions, 5y demand has also increased steadily this year,” Barclays said, noting that the bid-to-cover ratio increased to 2.61x in July from 2.48x at the beginning of the year. “Despite weak performance over the past few months, the July auction was strong, stopping through 1bp,” Barclays says, “overall, performance in 2018 is better than in 2017. The average tail was 0bp, compared with +0.5bp during the same period in 2017.” In terms of breakdown, last month, domestic investors took 65% of the issue (highest in a decade). “Rarely has domestic participation breached the 60% threshold, underscoring continued interest from this investor category,” Barclays wrote. However, on the other side of the coin, foreign participation continues to decline, dropping to 8% in July vs levels just under 20% at the start of the year.

Daily FX Wrap: Loonie leaps, Dollar creaks and Lira/Rand all over the place
content:
CAD/CHF

A real tussle to end Tuesday’s EU session ahead of the G10 pack, with the Loonie making a late charge on the back of latest US-Canada trade comments via Mnuchin who claims that a deal, ala Mexico, may be struck this week and he does no foresee many contentious issues to be resolved. Usd/Cad down through 1.2900 and eyeing the 200 DMA next (around 1.2842) to rival the Franc that continues to test the same key tech support circa 0.9750 on more short covering and positional adjustment.

DXY

Lost grip of previous August lows amidst widespread Greenback weakness and retreats vs EMs, with the index through 94.500 and down near 94.425 before regaining some composure after a jump in US consumer confidence.

EUR/NZD

The next best majors and grinding out gains vs the Usd for much of the day, with the single currency up through 1.1700 and Kiwi extending its rebound from recent lows a bit further above 0.6700 on a broad improvement in risk sentiment.

GBP/AUD/JPY

A bit more reluctant to join the overall trend with Cable unable to really build on 1.2900+ levels and the Pound slipping to fresh multi-month lows vs the Eur (around 0.9080) on heightened risk of a hard or no deal Brexit. Meanwhile, political instability and the US-China trade impasse continue to hamper the Aud around 0.7350, while Usd/Jpy remained anchored to 111.00.

EM

Try and Zar among the big movers yet again, and both very volatile, with the Lira retesting lows vs the Usd in the 6.2000+ area, then paring declines briefly on reports that Germany may be mulling financial assistance for Turkey, before re-weakening on later headlines suggesting that the aid being considered is not in cash form. Similarly, the Rand got a boost on the news that SA’s expropriation bill proposed by the ANC has been withdrawn, but fell back when details revealed that the constitutional change is still on the agenda for review. Usd/Zar down through 14.0000 at one stage vs 14.2425 at the high, and now circa 14.1500.

28th August 2018

Earnings

  • Best Buy (BBY) Q2 Adj. EPS USD 0.91 vs. Exp. USD 0.83, revenue USD 9.38bln vs. Exp. USD 9.28bln, raises FY19 guidance. Sees Q3 Adj. EPS USD 0.79 -0.84, consensus USD 0.92. In talks with government on how to minimise impact from Tariffs. (Newswires)

  • Phibro Animal Health (PAHC) Q4 Adj. EPS USD 0.46 vs. Exp. USD 0.42, revenue USD 0.212bln vs. Exp. USD 0.208bln. Lowers FY19 EPS guidance. Raises quarterly dividend to USD 0.12/shr from USD 0.10/shr. (Newswires)
  • Hain Celestial (HAIN) Q4 Adj. EPS USD 0.27 vs. Exp. USD 0.26, revenue USD 0.619bln vs. Exp. USD 0.629bln. (Newswires)
  • Heico (HEI) Q3 EPS USD 0.49 vs. Exp. USD 0.45, revenue USD 0.465bln vs. Exp. USD 0.439bln. Raises FY18 revenue growth to 20%-21% from 18%-20%. (Newswires)
  • DSW (DSW) Q2 Adj. EPS USD 0.63 vs. Exp USD 0.46, revenue USD 0.795bln vs. Exp. USD 0.689bln. raises FY18 Adj. EPS view. (Newswires)
  • Tiffany (TIF) Q2 EPS USD 1.17 vs. Exp. USD 1.01, revenue USD 1.1bln vs. Exp. USD 1.04bln. Q2 comparable store sales increased by 8%, net inventories at July 31st were 8% above the prior year. Raises FY18 outlook, FY18 EPS view to USD 4.65-4.80 from USD 4.50-4.70, consensus USD 4.75. (Newswires)
  • KLX Inc. (KLXI) Q2 Adj. EPS USD 1.31 vs. Exp. USD 1.10, revenue USD 0.527bln vs. Exp. USD 0.496bln. (Newswires)

DJIA

  • Boeing (BA) – The plane manufacturer sees the greatest global demand for aviation personnel, including crews, technician and pilots, for the next 20 years in the Asia Pacific region. (Newswires)

  • FirstEnergy (FE) – The utility group entered settlement agreement with its subsidiary FirstEnergy Solutions to settle creditors’ and other parties’ proceedings. (Newswires)
  • Fortive (FTV) – The co. begins its split-off exchange offer for Automation & Specialty business in relation to its previously announced combination of A&S susiness with Altra Industrial Motion (AIMC). (Newswires)
  • General Growth Properties (GGP) - Arista Networks (ANET) to replace the co. in S&P 500 at open on September 28th following Brookfield Property Partners (BPY) acquisition of GGP, a deal expected to be completed soon. (Newswires)

  • Phillips 66 (PSX) – The oil group is partnering up with Ryze Renewables for the construction of renewable diesel plants in Nevada. (Newswires)
  • US automakers (TM, GM, F, FCAU) - Mexico's Economy Minister Guajardo announced the new trade deal with the US would have to be tweaked, particularly the rules of origin, if it ends up as a bilateral agreement without Canada. Nonetheless the new US -Mexico pact eases concern in the auto industry. White House Economic Adviser Kudlow stated auto tariffs on Canada possible if no trade deal reached. (WSJ/CNBC)

NASDAQ 100

He tweeted ‘Google search results for 'Trump News' shows only the viewing/reporting of Fake New Media. In other words, they have it RIGGED, for me & others, so that almost all stories & news is BAD. Fake CNN is prominent. Republican/Conservative & Fair Media is shut out. Illegal? 96% of.......results on 'Trump News' are from National Left-Wing Media, very dangerous. Google & others are suppressing voices of Conservatives and hiding information and news that is good. They are controlling what we can & cannot see. This is a very serious situation-will be addressed!’. (Twitter)
  • Amazon (AMZN) – Amazon Canada has launched a new prime membership plan at USD 7.99/mth. (Newswires)
  • Biogen (BIIB) – The healthcare co. and Eisai (ESALY) announced results for Phase 1b study of aducanumab for AD or Alzheimer disease, which were in line with previous interim analysis. (Newswires)
  • Electronic Arts (EA) – The video game maker cancelled three tournaments of its Madden NFL 19 football game after a competitor who lost a tournament attacked with a gun, killing two users and causing injuries to 11 others. (Newswires)
  • Facebook (FB) – India’s Supreme Court is waiting for a response from WhatsApp over a think-tank's petition. Note WhatsApp is already facing pressure in India due to fake news. (Newswires)
  • Illumina (ILMN) – The healthcare group announced the China National Drug Administration approved MiSeqDx System, a next-generation sequencing system to be distributed in hospital around China. (Newswires)
  • Qualcomm (QCOM) – The chipmaker reports preliminary results of tender offer and based on the preliminary results it sold 76,205,230 shares at or below USD 67.50 in cash. (Newswires)

  • Tesla (TSLA) – Canaccord say Elon Musk may have to be removed as CEO of the co., and have trimmed their Model 3 expectations for Q3, with PT lowered to USD 316. Elsewhere, a judge dismissed a lawsuit submitted by a shareholder alleging the automaker made false statements about its Model 3 production, though the case is not completely closed. Separately, the automaker’s looming debt remains even after CEO Elon Musk decided not to take the co. private.  (Newswires/The Verge)

RANsquawk Daily US Opening News - 28th August 2018
content:
To download the report, please click here
If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal.
To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category.

  • European equities trade mixed (Eurostoxx 50 -0.1%), UK’s FTSE 100 outperforms as it plays catch-up
  • The Dollar has lost more ground vs most G10/major rivals, but remains mixed vs EMs
  • Looking ahead, highlights include a speech by ECB’s Praet, and weekly API crude inventories

ASIA

Asian equity markets traded mostly higher as the region got a tailwind from US where the S&P 500 and Nasdaq extended on record highs with sentiment supported after US and Mexico reached a trade agreement. This lifted the ASX 200 (+0.6%) back above the 6300 level with gains led by outperformance in financials, while Nikkei 225 (+0.1%) was underpinned by a weaker currency but with upside capped by resistance around 23000. Shanghai Comp. (-0.1%) and Hang Seng (+0.3%) both initially conformed to the positive tone although the mainland then failed to sustain gains amid ongoing US-China trade uncertainty and as focus shifts to earnings with 3 of China’s big 4 banks to announce results today. Finally, 10yr JGBs traded subdued with demand sapped as focus centred on riskier assets and following weaker demand at the enhanced liquidity auction for longer dated JGBs.

PBoC skipped open market operations for a net daily drain of CNY 50bln. (Newswires)


PBoC set CNY mid-point at 6.8052 (Prev. 6.8508)

HKMA buys HKD 7.85bln as HKD hits the weak end of the trading range. (Newswires) This follows earlier reports the HKMA purchased HKD 2.8bln overnight and HKD 3.93bln yesterday to defend the trading band.

China Premier Li says China treats both domestic and international companies equally, and firmly upholds multilateralism, pledging to adopt stricter intellectual property rights, saying they will not allow forced technology transfers. (Newswires)

US

White House Economic Adviser Kudlow said Mexico-US trade agreement is a significant victory for the economy and that they would like a good deal with Canada but may resort to auto tariffs if Canada rejects the deal. Kudlow also commented that US-Mexico trade agreement can be pushed through Congress and stated ‘will see’ in regards to Canada, while Kudlow also commented that that they have things cooking with EU and that China should just agree to some of the US trade demands.

EU/UK

US President Trump and German Chancellor Merkel agreed on more discussions concerning US-EU trade barriers. (Newswires)

UK PM May reportedly signalled a no-deal Brexit is not the end of the world. (Newswires)

UK PM May is to announce plans to boost UK’s in Africa post-Brexit. (BBC)

The French Government is to prepare contingency plans in the case the EU and UK fail to agree terms of Brexit. (Newswires)

German Foreign Minister Maas says expects US to revoke threatened tariffs and stop threatening the European auto industry

CENTRAL BANKS

BoE's Carney reportedly asked to remain BoE Governor until 2020 (vs. originally ending 2019). UK Treasury spokesman says they do not recognize the Evening Standard report on BoE Carney's extension (Evening Standard/Newswires)

GEOPOLITICAL

US Secretary of State Pompeo said Iran does not control Strait of Hormuz which is an international waterway and that the US will continue to ensure freedom of navigation and free flow of commerce in international waterways. (Newswires)

Russia plans to respond to US sanctions according to reports citing Foreign Minister Lavrov. (Tass)

Iranian President Rouhani said Tehran will defeat economic challenges and anti-Iranian officials in the White House. (Newswires)

EQUITIES

European equities trade mixed (Eurostoxx 50 -0.1%) with underperformance in Italy’s FTSE MIB with Italian banks plumbing the depths while UK’s FTSE 100 outperforms as it plays catch-up following a public holiday on Monday. In terms of sectors, material names outperform on the back of firmer base metal prices while telecom names underperform. For stock specifics, Faurecia (+4.4%) climbed to the top if the Stoxx 600 following an upgrade at Kepler Cheuvreux while Sybank (-9.8%) and Baloise (-3.4%) share fell amid disappointing earnings

FX

USD - The Dollar has lost more ground vs most G10/major rivals, but remains mixed vs EMs, as the Try continues to weaken in contrast to the Cny (and Cnh in response) that saw the strongest fixing in more than a year overnight. Hence, the index has been drifting down further below 95.000 within a new 94.920-595 range, with nearest supports seen at early August lows (circa 94.491), assuming 94.500 does not hold.

CHF - The Franc is benefiting most from the weaker Greenback and trading close to 0.9750, though not really outperforming in cross terms as Eur/Chf holds firmly above 1.1400.

EUR/CAD/NZD - All mildly firmer vs the Usd, with the single currency extending yesterday’s post-Ifo recovery gains to around 1.1700 and not really hindered by considerably weaker than forecast Eurozone headline M3 data, while the Loonie has breached 1.2950 through heavy offers layered down to 1.2940 and the Kiwi is back probing 0.6700. Back to the Cad, renewed NAFTA or updated US-Mexican style trade agreement hopes continue to prop the currency and on that note a phone call between President Trump and Canadian PM Trudeau is said to have been constructive, according to the latter.

GBP - Mixed fortunes for the Pound as Cable revisits 1.2900 by virtue of the aforementioned broad Usd downturn, but Eur/Gbp climbs towards 0.9075 on heightened prospects of a no deal Brexit. Note: reports about Governor Carney being approached to extend his term until 2020 from 2019 sparked some limited Gbp weakness but not sustained and UK Treasury has declined to comment.

AUD/JPY - Narrowly mixed vs the Usd around 0.7350 and 111.00 respectively, with the Aud undermined by the ongoing US-China import tariff stand-off, but Jpy gleaning some support due to its safe-haven status, the Dollar’s demise and key chart levels/supply (unlike Eur/Jpy that touched 130.00 earlier amidst macro, leverage and fast money buying).

SEK - The G10 laggard, and largely due to significantly weaker than expected Swedish retail sales data, with Eur/Sek up to 10.6675 at one stage.

FIXED INCOME

content:
**EUROPEAN EQUITY COVERAGE WILL ONLY COVER COMPANIES IN THE STOXX 600 OR COMPANIES OF SYSTEMIC IMPORTANCE TO PARTICULAR SECTORS**

28th August 2018

The Daily European Equity Opening News is uploaded at 0700BST/0100CDT recapping all of the overnight equity news

From 0700BST/0100CDT all equity news will be covered in real time over the audio and headline feed and the full audio rundown will be at 0715BST/0115CDT.

There will be an additional audio rundown at 0750BST/0150CDT recapping any company news which has hit the wires since 0715BST/0115CDT ahead of the European equity open

ASIA

Asian equity markets traded mostly higher as the region got a tailwind from US where the S&P 500 and Nasdaq extended on record highs with sentiment supported after US and Mexico reached a trade agreement. This lifted the ASX 200 (+0.7%) back above the 6300 level with gains led by outperformance in financials, while Nikkei 225 (+0.4%) was underpinned by a weaker currency but with upside capped by resistance around 23000. Shanghai Comp. (Unch) and Hang Seng (+0.3%) both initially conformed to the positive tone although the mainland then failed to sustain gains amid ongoing US-China trade uncertainty and as focus shifts to earnings with 3 of China’s big 4 banks to announce results today. Finally, 10yr JGBs traded subdued with demand sapped as focus centred on riskier assets and following weaker demand at the enhanced liquidity auction for longer dated JGBs.

FTSE

Melrose (MRO LN) – The co. has started the GKN break-up with the GBP 1.8bln sale of its powder metallurgy division, according to sources. (Newswires)

Rolls-Royce (RR/ LN) – Fred Olsen opts for MTU engines and service supplied by Co. for its new fast ferries. (Newswires)

OTHER UK COMPANIES

John Wood Group (WG/ LN) – The co. have secured a new 4 year contract with Total Denmark. (Newswires)

DAX

BROKER MOVES

E.ON (EOAN GY) DOWNGRADED TO HOLD FROM BUY AT JEFFERIES

RWE (RWE GY) UPGRADED TO BUY FROM HOLD AT JEFFERIES

CONTINENTAL (CON GY) DOWNGRADED TO NEUTRAL FROM OVERWEIGHT AT JP MORGAN

SMI

Nestlé (NESN SW) – The co. and Starbucks (SBUX) have closed the USD 7.15bln deal for the perpetual global licence of combined packaged goods and food service products. (Newswires)

Roche (ROG SW) – CEO of the Diagnostic division and member of the Corporate Executive Committee resigns, effective 30th Sept. (Newswires)

OTHER SWISS COMPANIES

Flughafen Zurich (FHZN SW) – H1 profit of CHF 84.5mln, revenue +10.5% to CHF 540.2mln, EBITDA and profit expected to be higher in 2018 vs. Prev. (Newswires)

Baloise Holdings (BALN SW) – H1 profit attributable to shareholders CHF 269.7mln vs. Prev. CHF 299.0mln, overall volume of business -3.6% to CHF 5.468bln, combined net ratio at 94.1% vs. Prev. 94.1%. (Newswires)

PAN EUROPE

Automotive Names – The US and Mexico agreed to scrap the existing NAFTA agreement and go into an individual deal with Mexico. (Newswires)

Watchmaking Names (LVMH – LVMH IM; Swatch – UHR SW; Richemont – CFR SW) – The Swiss competition authority has said they will not open an investigation into watchmakers. (Newswires)

Atlantia (ATL IM) – Italy’s Deputy PM Di Maio said the only solution following the bridge collapse is to nationalise toll motorways. (Newswires)

Fincantieri (FCT IM) – Co.’s is said to potentially re-build Genoa’s collapsed bridge (Newswires)

US

 * SPX +0.8% at 2897, NDX +1.0% at 7559, DJI +1.0% at 26052. SECTORS: Energy +0.7%, Materials +1.4%, Industrials +1.2%, Cons Discretionary +0.7%, Cons Staples +0.1%, Healthcare +0.3%, Financials +1.4%, Tech +0.9%, Telecoms +0.4%, Utilities -0.7%.

* SECTORS: Most sectors pushed higher on the back of U.S./Mexico trade talk progressions, primarily industrials where Boeing (BA) and Caterpillar (CAT) made strong leads; automakers too, Ford (F) General Motors (GM) and Fiat Chrysler (FCAU) being the biggest movers. The defensive utilities sector found itself dropping on the progressive sentiment. Chinese-based tech names (JD, BIDU, BABA, IQ) traded higher after the Chinese Central Bank intervened to stabilise the yuan.

content:
To download the report, please click here
If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal.
To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category.

  • Asian equity markets traded mostly higher as the region got a tailwind from US where the S&P 500 and Nasdaq extended on record highs
  • In FX markets, the DXY remained below the 95.00 level following a 2-day selldown
  • Looking ahead, highlights include a speech by ECB’s Praet, and weekly API crude inventories

ASIA

Asian equity markets traded mostly higher as the region got a tailwind from US where the S&P 500 and Nasdaq extended on record highs with sentiment supported after US and Mexico reached a trade agreement. This lifted the ASX 200 (+0.7%) back above the 6300 level with gains led by outperformance in financials, while Nikkei 225 (+0.4%) was underpinned by a weaker currency but with upside capped by resistance around 23000. Shanghai Comp. (Unch) and Hang Seng (+0.3%) both initially conformed to the positive tone although the mainland then failed to sustain gains amid ongoing US-China trade uncertainty and as focus shifts to earnings with 3 of China’s big 4 banks to announce results today. Finally, 10yr JGBs traded subdued with demand sapped as focus centred on riskier assets and following weaker demand at the enhanced liquidity auction for longer dated JGBs.

PBoC skipped open market operations for a net daily drain of CNY 50bln. (Newswires)


PBoC set CNY mid-point at 6.8052 (Prev. 6.8508)


UK/EU

US President Trump and German Chancellor Merkel agreed on more discussions concerning US-EU trade barriers. (Newswires)

UK PM May reportedly signalled a no-deal Brexit is not the end of the world. (Newswires)

UK PM May is to announce plans to boost UK’s in Africa post-Brexit. (BBC)

The French Government is to prepare contingency plans in the case the EU and UK fail to agree terms of Brexit. (Newswires)

Reports noted that UK and EU are to agree to push back its Brexit agreement deadline by 4 weeks to a ‘hard deadline’ in mid-November. (Telegraph)


FX

In FX markets, the DXY remained below the 95.00 level following a 2-day selldown although resistance in EUR/USD and GBP/USD at 1.1700 and 1.2900 respectively, provided the greenback with some mild reprieve overnight. JPY was predominantly weaker on the heightened risk appetite which helped USD/JPY edge a firmer footing on the 111.00 handle, while antipodeans also marginally pulled back. Elsewhere, MXN continued to pare its trade-related gains and CNY also softened despite the PBoC strengthening the fix by the most in over a year.


COMMODITIES

Commodities were lacklustre overnight with WTI crude future flat after failing to hold above the USD 69.00/bbl level, while gold was also uneventful with the rebound in the precious metal stalling at around 2-week highs as the greenback began to nurse losses. Elsewhere, copper underperformed amid underperformance in mainland China and weakness in Chinese commodities with rebar prices dampened on ongoing trade tensions and after the US imposed anti-dumping duties on some steel and iron products from China.

China Dalian Commodity Exchange announced to reduce trading limit and margin requirements for iron ore, coke and coking coal futures effective today. (Newswires)

US Commerce Department issued preliminary duty determination of between 58.75%-172.51% on certain steel wheels from China and imposed anti-dumping duties on Chinese-made cast iron soil pipe. (Newswires)


GEOPOLITICAL

US Secretary of State Pompeo said Iran does not control Strait of Hormuz which is an international waterway and that the US will continue to ensure freedom of navigation and free flow of commerce in international waterways. (Newswires)

Syrian Air Defences were reported to be on full alert due to concerns of a possible US strike. (Newswires)

Russia plans to respond to US sanctions according to reports citing Foreign Minister Lavrov. (Tass)

Iranian President Rouhani said Tehran will defeat economic challenges and anti-Iranian officials in the White House. (Newswires)


US

Treasuries were sold in the European morning in sympathy with bunds following a solid IFO report out of Germany. There was additional selling as the S&P 500 hit fresh record highs, carrying on from last week. Additionally, selling action was spurred after the US and Mexico reached a bilateral trade deal. The US Treasury sold $36bln of 2-year notes with the high-yield coming in on the screws (2.655%). The participation metrics were in-line with recent auctions and saw average demand, with indirects taking the largest portion whilst dealers were awarded the biggest share since May and directs the smallest portion since February. US 10-year T-notes settled 5+ ticks lower at 120-11.

US President Trump said he will terminate existing NAFTA agreement to go into the deal made with Mexico, while he added he will either put tariffs on Canada or reach a negotiated deal with them. In related news, In related news, US President Trump had a call with Canadian PM Trudeau which the latter described as constructive and was said to be hopeful for a successful conclusion. (Newswires)

White House Economic Adviser Kudlow said Mexico-US trade agreement is a significant victory for the economy and that they would like a good deal with Canada but may resort to auto tariffs if Canada rejects the deal. Kudlow also commented that US-Mexico trade agreement can be pushed through Congress and stated ‘will see’ in regards to Canada, while Kudlow also commented that that they have things cooking with EU and that China should just agree to some of the US trade demands.

Mexico Foreign Minister Videgaray said it would be ideal if there was a trilateral NAFTA but added that Mexico can accept a bilateral, while he added US and Mexico will go ahead if US and Canada cannot agree. In related news, a Canadian official said flexibility is required in order to get a NAFTA deal this week and that several issues are still outstanding for Canada, while Canada's Foreign Minister Freeland is said to be heading to Washington on Tuesday for trade talks. (Newswires)

US President Trump said he is working on a major infrastructure project and a massive roadway. (Newswires)

(-0.1%) and Hang Seng (+0.3%) initially conformed to the positive tone but the mainland then failed to sustain gains amid ongoing US-China trade uncertainty and as focus shifts to earnings with 3 of China’s big 4 banks to announce results today.

In FX markets, the DXY remains subdued and sits below the 95.00 level following a 2-day selldown, although resistance in EUR/USD and GBP/USD at 1.1700 and 1.2900 respectively has provided the greenback some mild reprieve overnight. Elsewhere, JPY is predominantly weaker on the heightened risk appetite with USD/JPY edging a firmer footing on the 111.00 handle, while antipodeans have marginally pulled back as CNY gives back some of its gains despite the PBoC strengthening the fix by the most in over a year.

Finally, 10yr JGBs are flat with demand sapped as focus centres on riskier assets and ahead of an enhanced liquidity auction for longer dated bonds.
